entry.title: Are We in a Bubble?
entry.content:
A lot of people are asking if we’re in a bubble. To figure that out, the first place we should look is at the numbers themselves.

Buying a Home?  Search All Charlotte Area Homes for Sale 
Selling Your Charlotte home? Get a Free Home Value Report

A lot of people have been asking if right now is a good time to buy or sell. But, another broader question I’m hearing a lot is, “Are we in a bubble?”

To figure that out, I think it’s important to look at the numbers. Over the last three years, the market has seen consistent growth and the interest rates have generally stayed low. 

We can see from this that there isn’t a very high likelihood that the Feds will be raising interest rates in a significant way. In fact, some people are saying interest rates could even drop.

The lower interest rates are, the more people can afford. This is especially important since the somewhat drastic increases we’ve seen in prices over the last two to three years. Right now in our area, we’re starting to see prices similar to those we saw in 2006, 2007, and 2008. 

Though interest rates typically rise along with price, this isn’t a trend we’re currently seeing. We can expect prices to continue to rise. 

We’re also seeing homes spending fewer days on market, as well as lower inventory overall. 
If you’re thinking of buying, now is still a good time.
However, if you’re thinking of buying, now is still a good time. 

If you’re considering selling, the most important thing is to pay attention to supply and demand within the market. 

Overall, I’d have to say that most people would not agree that we’re in a bubble. 

If you have any other questions or would like more information, feel free to give me a call or send me an email. I look forward to hearing from you soon.

entry.title: How Do You Choose a Quality Agent?
entry.content:
When you are looking for an agent to help with your real estate transaction, how can you know if they will do a good job?

Buying a Home?  Search All Charlotte Area Homes for Sale 
Selling Your Charlotte home? Get a Free Home Value Report
With the recent influx of agents into our area’s market, a lot of people have come to me asking, “How do I find the right agent?” 

The answer depends on what kind of real estate transaction you’re about to undertake. If you are in the market to purchase a home you should be looking for a lender.

But don’t settle for your first encounter, be sure to shop around to get the best rates and the best terms and conditions on your mortgage. You should also get a buyer’s roadmap. A buyer’s roadmap will show you how we get priority access to all the best deals on the market. 

This will help you win out against the competition. Having the roadmap will be your guide to success as a buyer, but you’ll still need a quality agent. When looking for the right agent, be sure to ask how many homes they sell per year, how well they know the area, and how well they know financing.

Sellers will need a game plan, as well. Having a selling guide and using high-quality marketing will be key. My team and I offer a 151-step marketing guide that can help you have as smooth and successful a transaction as possible. 
Very few other agents, or teams of agents, can do what we can.
Full-disclosure, full-detail marketing strategies are also something we do. From 3D tours to aerial drone shots and more, we have all the resources to help our sellers make their listing as attractive as possible. We also offer a 75-point photography checklist designed to ensure that your home is being presented in the best light.

Very few other agents, or teams of agents, can do what we can—let alone at such a high level. 

To find out if an agent will be able to get you top dollar, there are a few questions you should ask as a seller. How many homes have they sold this year? Do they have a resume?  

With as many agents as are coming in our area, we’re seeing a few of them underpricing homes and therefore only selling between two to four properties a year. Selling quickly isn’t worth it if an agent is undercutting their client’s profit by thousands.

One of the things that sets my team apart is that we only accept full price offers for our clients. You need an agent who has a game plan for getting you at or above list price.  

If you have any other questions or would like more information, feel free to give us a call or send us an email. We look forward to hearing from you soon.

link.title: How Do You Choose a Quality Agent?

entry.title: Who Can You Trust to Sell Your Rental Property?
entry.content:
If you want to sell your home that's currently being rented, should you try to sell it through the leasing company? Here's why I advise against it.

Buying a Home?  Search All Charlotte Area Homes for Sale 
Selling Your Charlotte home? Get a Free Home Value Report
There are a few common questions I've received in recent weeks that I wanted to address for you.

Q: Is there any benefit to choosing a team of real estate agents versus a leasing company?

A: A client had a home rented and was looking to sell it. The people leasing the home really wanted to list the house. I told them that the problem was that they wanted to list the house—not try to find a buyer and sell it in a reasonable amount of time for top dollar.
Don't ask someone to sell your home unless they sell homes regularly at a high level.
Someone once told me that when you ask someone to do something they don't normally do at a very high level, you probably won't get the best results. Just like you wouldn't call your kids' orthodontist for a root canal, you shouldn't call your leasing company to sell your house. 

If you have a home that's rented that you're looking to sell, don't hesitate to give me a call or send me an email. I'd be happy to help!

link.title: Who Can You Trust to Sell Your Rental Property?

entry.title: A Few Things to Know Before Buying New Construction
entry.content:
Whatever you do, don’t start the new home building process without an agent’s help. You could be setting yourself up for failure without even trying.

Buying a Home?  Search All Charlotte Area Homes for Sale 
Selling Your Charlotte home? Get a Free Home Value Report
We’ve been noticing that a lot of our clients over the years have misconceptions about how buying new construction homes work. We wanted to go through the process and clarify any questions you may have today. 

If you’re considering building a new home, it’s always best to go into the process with an agent who has experience working with and negotiating these kinds of deals. You might think that you could save some money as a buyer by not using an agent, but you would be completely wrong. 

If a builder knows you don’t have representation, they are going to run you over and you will end up overpaying for a property. Until you have an agent who knows what they’re doing when it comes to negotiating with these builders, you won’t have as successful of a home purchase as you could have had. 
An agent can help you get a lower interest rate and better upgrades.
By working with an agent, you can get a lower interest rate, better upgrades, and other discounts that you wouldn’t be able to get on your own. The expertise of an agent really pays off in situations like this. If you’re working with one of our buyer’s agents here at the Dan Jones Team, let them know if you’re interested in this kind of property.

Speaking of our great agents, let me give a shout out to one of our new agents, Karen, who has been doing fantastic as of late putting homes under contract and is working with several new construction buyers right now.

In the meantime, if you have any questions for us, don’t hesitate to give us a call or send us an email. We look forward to hearing from you.

link.title: A Few Things to Know Before Buying New Construction

entry.title: The Latest News From the Charlotte Real Estate Market
entry.content:
It’s not summer yet, but the Charlotte real estate market is the hottest market we have ever seen. I’ll go over more details for you today.

Buying a Home?  Search All Charlotte Area Homes for Sale 
Selling Your Charlotte home? Get a Free Home Value Report
If you are thinking about selling a home in the next three to six months, you should know that the real estate market is on fire right now. 

This is the hottest market that we’ve seen. Homes are selling after 30 to 40 days on the market; some homes are selling in 60 to 70 days. This is a much faster pace than the usual 130 to 140 days.
On average, homes are selling in 30 to 40 days.
If you are thinking of buying or selling a home, we would love to show you what we do differently to help you reach your real estate goals. We can sell houses in half of the average days on market; in other words, we can sell your home in 15 to 20 days. 

One marketing tool we like to implement is our “Full Price Offers Only” sign that we put on each of our listings. 

For buyers, interest rates are still incredibly low, but they are starting to creep up a bit. Now is a great time to jump into the market while rates are still low. 

If you have any questions about navigating our current market, give me a call or send me an email. I would be happy to help you!

link.title: The Latest News From the Charlotte Real Estate Market

entry.title: Why You Should Hire Us to Sell Your House
entry.content:
If you’re thinking about selling your house this year, you need to reach out to us. Allow me to explain why.

Buying a Home?  Search All Charlotte Area Homes for Sale 
Selling Your Charlotte home? Get a Free Home Value Report
If you’re thinking about selling your house this year, you need to reach out to our company.

We do a lot of things to sell your house quickly and for top dollar, including our VIP Seller Program. This is a ‘coming soon’ type of program that markets your home to thousands of people before it even hits the market. Our average days on market has been cut in half simply because of this program.

It could be the difference in you needing to make an extra mortgage payment or two on your home while you sell, and that’s huge. 

We also offer a 151-step marketing tool, which we’ll happily send you. Whether you’ve sold a home recently or not, you’d be surprised at all the things we do to sell your house for top dollar every time. 

We’d also be happy to send you our 2016 resume. We sold more than 200 homes last year, and we’re well on our way to 250 to 300 sales this year. 
We sold more than 200 homes in 2016 and we’re well on our way to 250 this year.
When you sell your house, most agents will come out for a comparative market analysis (CMA) based on square footage, but it’s impossible to know the exact condition that every single home sold under. It could have been the result of a divorce, an estate sale, or a short sale, to name a few. 

We do a full equity evaluation based on a market absorption sheet. We’ll look at everything that’s happened in the last 12 to 24 months to figure out where we need to be and what we need to do to sell your house for top dollar. 

If you’re thinking about selling, it’s a must. Just give us a call or send us an email if you’re thinking about selling, we’d love to help.

link.title: Why You Should Hire Us to Sell Your House

entry.title: Stand out on the Market By Doing These 4 Things
entry.content:
Today I’m going to go over some great, affordable ways to prepare your home for the spring market.

Buying a Home?  Search All Charlotte Area Homes for Sale 
Selling Your Charlotte home? Get a Free Home Value Report
If you’re thinking about selling your home this spring, there are some great affordable ways you can prepare to ensure you get top dollar. 
Doing the basics is going to get you the biggest return.
  1. Declutter. Box up all of the items you don’t need and put them in a storage unit. Decluttering ensures your home feels cozy, and buyers are more likely to see the value in a decluttered home. 
  2. Repaint the doors. Adding a fresh coat of paint to the doors will make them feel and look new. Buyers will take notice and really appreciate that detail. 
  3. Repaint the trim. You don’t need to paint every bit of trim in the house, but make sure you hit the main walking areas, bathrooms, hallways, and the kitchen. 
  4. Spruce up the landscaping. Get some mulch and freshen things up. Also, make sure two days before you get pictures taken you mow the grass and clear the driveway off.
Assuming there are no major issues with your carpet or flooring, hitting the basics is going to get you the biggest return. By doing so, your home will be 75% more likely to sell than other homes. Just remember not to overimprove your home by taking on huge projects like the ones on HGTV. Those projects won’t always get you the best return.

If you have any other questions, please feel free to give me a call or send me an email. I look forward to hearing from you!

link.title: Stand out on the Market By Doing These 4 Things

entry.title: Why Work With One of Our Buyer Specialists?

Our market moves fast, especially for buyers. You can gain an advantage on your competition by hiring the right people to help you.

Selling Your Charlotte home? Get a Free Home Value Report
What makes our buyer specialists different from the rest? There are a lot of things, actually. If you’ve spoken to one of them already, you have an idea of what we’re all about. However, there are a lot of specific advantages to using our services over other firms out there.

There are so many real estate agents out there, but not many of them specialize in getting their clients priority access to all the best deals on the market. If you’ve been looking for a home lately, you already know how fast the market moves. That’s why we prioritize getting our clients a backstage pass to the MLS so they are aware of homes that match their criteria as soon as they hit the market, sometimes even before.
We give our clients a backstage pass to the MLS.
Another unique advantage our team offers is that we are coached at a very high level. This means we are more in-tune with the market, have better negotiating skills, and know how to handle stressful situations better than most agents. 

The average agent sells five homes per year and doesn’t know how to get their buyers the best deal possible. With our unique training and experience, we do. If you have any questions for us or would like to work with one of our expert buyer specialists, give us a call or send us an email. We look forward to hearing from you.

entry.title: What’s Going on in the Charlotte Market?
entry.content:
The Charlotte market is on fire right now! I’ll go over what’s making our real estate market so hot today.  

Buying a Home?  Search All Charlotte Area Homes for Sale 
Selling Your Charlotte home? Get a Free Home Value Report


The Charlotte real estate market is on fire right now, so I wanted to give you a rundown on what’s happening. 

Many people thought home prices would come down as interest rates increased, but that hasn’t been the case so far. However, price per square foot is expected to decrease as interest rates continue to rise in 2017. 

So, if you’re thinking about selling your home or investment property this year, now is the time. In fact, some people are saying that this year will be the best year ever to sell an investment property. 
2017 could be the best year ever to sell investment property.
If you’re looking to make a move, whether you are downsizing or upgrading to a larger home, right now is the best time to take advantage of a low interest rate and secure the most profit from your current home sale. 

All in all, right now is a great time to buy or sell real estate. Also, if you have been thinking about buying new construction, I know a lot of builders have been accepting contingency offers, so make sure you keep that in mind. 

If you have any further questions or want to discuss how you can take advantage of Charlotte’s hot market, please feel free to give me a call or send me an email. I look forward to hearing from you!

link.title: What’s Going on in the Charlotte Market?

entry.title: Great News for North Carolina Home Buyers
entry.content:
North Carolina recently brought back its $15,000 grant program. This is a great program for first-time home buyers. I’ll go over a few important details for you today. 

Buying a Home?  Search All Charlotte Area Homes for Sale 
Selling Your Charlotte home? Get a Free Home Value Report

Today I have some great news for North Carolina home buyers: the $15,000 grant program is back!

If you’re a first-time home buyer or if you haven’t owned a home in the last three years, you may be eligible for this program.

Basically, the state will give you $15,000 towards down payment assistance, closing costs, and/or buying the loan amount down. 

There are a few requirements that you have to meet in order to qualify for this program. 

First of all, you cannot make over a certain amount of money. Check in with your lender for the details. Secondly, you have to buy a home in the $240,000 to $245,000 price range. 
The state will give you $15,000 towards down payment assistance.
This is a great program for first-time home buyers. I certainly wish it was around back when I bought my home! 

If you are working with one of our agents already, they know tons about this program. Make sure you ask them about it. 

If you’re not a first-time home buyer but you know someone who is, make sure that they are looking in Mecklenburg or Cabarrus County in order to qualify for this program. 

Last October, 3,000 grants were issued to home buyers. There are not many left today. Get in touch with us to take advantage of this great loan program. We would be happy to help you!

link.title: Great News for North Carolina Home Buyers

entry.title: Why Is Now a Great Time to List Your Home?
entry.content:
There are a lot of serious buyers out in the market right now. Here’s why listing now will help you capture this segment of buyers.

Buying a Home?  Search All Charlotte Area Homes for Sale

entry.title: What Makes Zestimates Inaccurate?
entry.content:
Buying a home?  Search all Charlotte area homes for sale 
Selling your Charlotte home? Get a free home value report 

I’ve gotten a lot of questions recently about Zestimates, and I’m going to address them today. A Zestimate is just what its name implies - an estimate of your home’s value. An estimate is a reasonable approach to value in regard to real estate, but an estimate is, by definition, inexact. Enjoy using a Zestimate as a tool, but don’t be surprised by the inaccurate information that you receive from it.

Why are Zillow’s Zestimates so inaccurate? There are a few reasons. First off, Zillow doesn’t look at supply and demand. They look at recent comps, but not recent appraisals. They also pull from tax records, which can be extremely inaccurate as well. If you use that data, you could be misrepresenting your home’s value by as much as $60,000 or $70,000. Tax records aren’t a good tool for estimating a home’s value.


“
Your home could be worth $60,000 or $70,000 more than you think.

”


Another thing Zillow’s Zestimate doesn’t take into account is location. Your home may have five or six different good comparables, but Zillow won’t be able to determine whether you live in a location that would boost your home’s value. If you live on a golf course, cul-de-sac, or a wooded lot, Zillow would not factor that in.

Finally, Zestimates don’t take upgrades and updates into account. Your home’s value will be determined in the same way whether you have a fully remodeled kitchen, bathroom, or basement. Assigning a list price to your home based on a Zestimate could be hugely detrimental to your sale.

I have a rental property that Zillow recently told me is worth $80,000 more than it really is. If anyone out there would like to buy the home for the Zestimate price, let me know and we’ll get a contract written up. Otherwise, if you have any other questions or want to know what the true market value of your home is, give us a call. We would be happy to do an equity evaluation for you and give you a professional opinion on how much your home should sell for.

entry.title: What Are Some of the Hidden Costs of Selling a House?
entry.content:
Buying a home?  Search all Charlotte area homes for sale 
Selling your Charlotte home? Get a free home value report 

There are several hidden costs of selling a house people usually don’t find out about until they get to the closing table. What I want to talk about today are some of those major expenses.

First of all, if you haven’t lived in your house for very long, there is a good chance you’re going to be paying a capital gains tax. It’s a good idea to speak with your accountant to confer over this.

Next are the seller closing costs. A lot of agents like to beat around the bush about who pays what, but it’s important to know this up front when you’re deciding who you’re going to sell your home to and at what price. Closing costs consist of attorney’s fees and deed stamps.


“
It’s important to know your closing costs up front.

”


Repairs to the house is another cost to consider. They might be simple, or they might be complicated, but almost all homes end up having repairs. Just getting an electrician through the door can cost as much as $150. A lot of buyers also like to ask for a home warranty. We don’t encourage our sellers to buy those up front because we’d rather wait for the buyer to negotiate that in and move up the asking price of the home.

Finally, you have costs like additional repairs or attorney’s fees. If there are any title issues, we strongly suggest that you clear them up beforehand.

Be sure you’re aware of these omissions when it’s your time to sell so you’re prepared for the process. If you have any questions, please send me an email or give me a call. As always, I look forward to your referrals and talking to you soon.

entry.title: Pricing Errors that Cost Carolina Home Sellers Thousands
entry.content:
Buying a home?  Search all Charlotte area homes for sale 
Selling your Charlotte home? Get a free home value report 

Homeowners can lose thousands of dollars when they sell their house for a number of reasons. How is it possible to lose money when selling, you ask?

In Carolina, we're probably in one of the best seller’s markets we've seen in a decade. We have great comps to get homes sold, but when people are valuing their home, they aren't doing a full equity evaluation and really understanding what the market can absorb. Many people are simply getting a comparative market analysis (or CMA) and underpricing the home, only to see it sell in a few days for up to 6% less than they should have.

If your home is worth around $300,000 or more, that's a lot of money to leave on the table.


“
Pricing a home too high or too low will cost you in the long run.
”


Secondly, overpricing is a way people are throwing away money. I have people tell me they want to start their home priced $30,000 above what it should be. The downside is that the home's going to sit on the market for a long time, and even if you find a buyer, the home probably won't appraise for that price. If a home sits on the market, you'll have to lower the price. By the time the price comes down to where it should be, buyers will think there is something wrong with the house and they won't even come view it.


What you end up with is a house that sat on the market for around 200 days that ends up selling for up to 15% less than it should have if it was priced appropriately.

Finally, choosing the wrong agent can cause you to lose tens of thousands of dollars. You want to make sure the agent you hire has a full marketing budget to get your house proper exposure. There are a lot of new agents out there who just don't know the market. If you're not selling a lot of homes, they may end up underpricing and losing you money.

Let me know of any questions you have about pricing your home, or if you're considering buying or selling a home. I look forward to speaking with you!

Why is the market so hot? The main reason is we have very low supply and very high demand right now. We are shifting into a seller’s market as there are not a lot of homes to choose from. Properties that are prepared properly and positioned well in the market sell pretty quickly and for top dollar.

Secondly, interest rates are very low. Two or three years ago, many people suspected we would see 5.5% interest rates in 2016, but rates have held consistently over the last year or so. In fact, rates have actually come down a little bit. These low rates mean it is still very affordable for you to buy a slightly bigger home or even build a house.

These agents don’t necessarily know how to price your property for this market. You could lose 5% to 10% of your true home value when you underprice your property.

entry.title: 5 Reasons Why Sellers Don’t Like Agents
entry.content:
Buying a home?  Search all Charlotte area homes for sale 
Selling your Charlotte home? Get a free home value report 

Unfortunately, sometimes home sellers just don’t like real estate agents. There are five reasons that stand out.

I talk to a ton of sellers in the area and we sell a ton of homes, and I find the first reason is that sometimes agents just don’t listen. They just seem too busy, and that’s mainly because agents are usually a one-person show and just don’t have the resources to hire multiple people and do a great job for a client. They get too busy and forget all the necessary steps it takes to sell a home for top dollar.

Many agents are pushy as well. Some are so pushy that if you’re not ready to sign a contract with them right then and there, they won’t give you the time of day to go through your house or give you suggestions to sell for top dollar.

Another reason sellers don’t like agents is a lack of communication. This goes back to individuals who try to work by themselves and get caught up in too many things. You can’t show, market, and sell homes while telling 8,000 agents about the home, and do it all well. Sometimes people will tell me about agents who list a house, the house sits on the market for six months, and then the day before the contract expires, the agent shows up and suggests renewing the contract for six more months without speaking before then!

“
Everyone’s biggest fear is underpricing your home.

”

Probably everyone’s biggest fear is underpricing their home. It takes good data and market research to determine your home’s position, and your average agent doesn’t know that information. They don’t sell enough homes or know what buyers are looking for. It makes sellers upset when they see agents marketing themselves as a “neighborhood expert” when really they’ve only sold two area homes in the last eight years!

I hope you found this topic helpful. If you are thinking about selling or have any real estate questions, I’d be happy to speak with you about it. Contact me today!

entry.title: Four Ways to Ruin Your Home Sale
entry.content:
Buying a home?  Search all Charlotte area homes for sale 
Selling your Charlotte home? Get a free home value report 

When homes fail to sell on the market, it’s usually for the same reasons. Whether it’s because of bad communication or the wrong agent, these four things can ruin your home’s sale before it even gets put on the market. Here they are:

1.  Bad communication.
A lot of agents are a one-person show and simply don’t have time to do all the things they need to do in order to ensure a successful transaction. A one-person operation simply doesn’t have the time to communicate with all the people involved in the transaction. Trying to communicate with all the buyers, agents, inspectors, and lenders is difficult to do by yourself, and this generally results in communication between the seller and the agent being poor as well.

2. Pricing the home incorrectly. Overpricing and underpricing are bad. Overpricing your home will net you 5-10% less than if you priced at the right point from the beginning. Underpricing your home is also dangerous, and could cause you to get much less for your home than you thought.

“
The agent you choose shouldn’t be a formality.

”

3. Choosing the wrong agent.
A lot of people choose someone who is a friend or family member to sell their home because they feel obligated. The agent you choose shouldn’t be a formality, they should earn your business. You need an agent who knows the market, who is selling a lot of homes, and has the marketing budget to make sure your home gets exposure so it sells for top dollar.

4. Incorrectly positioning your home to sell.
A lot of agents will simply use an old version of a CMA (Comparative Market Analysis) to price your home. If that’s the only method your agent is using, it’s not valuable at all. Factors like your competition, your condition, and your location should also be used to determine where to position your home to make sure you succeed in getting top dollar.

Don’t be a seller that chooses an agent you will regret after 30 days of no showings. If you have any questions for us, or would like a copy of our VIP Seller’s Guide, don’t hesitate to reach out to us by phone or email. We’d be happy to help in any way we can.

entry.title: How Could Waiting to Buy in Charlotte Cost You Thousands?
entry.content:

How cheap is money right now and how much will monthly payments change should rates go up? These are questions on everyone’s mind right now, so today we’ll try to give you an idea of how interest rates affect our market. 



Traditionally, interest rates have been in the 8%-16% range. Right now, rates are still floating anywhere from 3.75% to 4.75%, depending on the loan type and the down payment amount. Although rates are currently near all-time lows, most experts are predicting rates to rise over the course of this year. 

For a $200,000 loan, if interest rates moved up .25%, your buying power would decrease by $10,000-$20,000, depending on what you’re looking to put down. So, if you are currently in the market for a $200,000 home, a rise of rates of only a quarter of a percent could affect your buying power by $20,000! If rates moved up .50%, you would then only be able to afford a $160,000 home! 

Because your ability to afford a home shifts drastically in the event of even a minor interest rate hike, we highly recommend making a home purchase before rates begin to rise!

entry.title: How Do You Know the Market You’re In?
entry.content:

Selling a Charlotte home?  Get a Home Price Evaluation 

How do you know what market we’re in? Markets change weekly, monthly, and quarterly. Today, we’ll cover the things you should look at.

Is the market flooded? What’s the inventory like? In the past two years, inventory has been below average. It’s been more of a seller’s market. With that, you need to examine your competition. There’s a possibility there isn't a lot of selection. Analyze the market’s supply and demand.


Look at interest rates. If interest rates were closer to six percent right now, the market could be a bit more flat and still where it’s easy for folks to acquire a loan.

Consider the average days on the market. Traditionally, Charlotte’s average has been 120 to 125 days on the market. It’s been like this for several years, even in surrounding areas. However, as inventory decreases, the average drops down to seventy or eighty days on the market.

Pay attention to the cost per square foot. Many homes have pools, extended decks, covered porches, and different floor plans. In general, the average cost per square foot has been $112 to $125. Ultimately, the cost per square foot has been increasing in the area.

entry.title: Why Should You Take CMAs with a Grain of Salt?
entry.content:
Buying a Charlotte home? Get a full home search 
Selling a Charlotte home?  Get a Home Price Evaluation 

Today, I want to discuss one of the most important aspects of the selling process: determining a list price.

A lot of agents will do a CMA, a competitive market analysis, as this is something agents are taught on their first day. With an ever-changing market, like the one we have in our area, it's important not to rely too heavily on a CMA. It will only give you a ballpark estimate of the home value because it doesn't consider the condition in which comparable homes were sold. CMAs just don't look into the details that can really affect a home's value.


In this market, you need to factor in the supply and demand. If you have a home with a pool, in the $300k-$400k price range, it may not be the best decision to try to sell if there are other homes in your price range on the market that also have pools. It's crucial to remember that there are better times and worse times to list a property!

A good agent is going to look at how many homes have sold in the last 90 days, how many homes failed to sell, how many homes are active, and how many homes are coming on the market per month to come up with percentages. At that point, your agent should be able to determine how much inventory there is, how much the market can absorb, and, ultimately, what price is the right price for your home in the given market. That price is going to play a huge role in how quickly your home sells!

Bottom line: be careful about CMAs! If you want the best results when selling, you need to work with someone who is going to go the extra mile to put the proper price on your home. If you have any questions about how we can do this for you, or if you need real estate assistance of any kind, don't hesitate to give us a call or shoot us an email. We would love to hear from you!

Today I just want to offer you some friendly advice if you're about to buy a home in Charlotte. What I'll tell you before anything else is that you need to interview the agent before you allow them to help you buy a home. Make sure that they sell at least 25 homes per year and that they do real estate full-time. Finding you a home is a big job, and you want a capable professional to help you purchase a home.


Another thing that has proved to be very helpful is when we get the buyer to write a personalized letter to the seller. This helps to put a face to your name instead of a number. Tell the seller why your family needs the property, and tell them what you plan to do with it. We've found that this can really pull the heart strings of the seller and help to get you the home.


Something else that I highly recommend is getting a pre-approval from the bank. A pre-qualification doesn't mean very much these days but if you can get pre-approved, then you'll look great to most home sellers. This proves that you can actually pay for the home, and that always puts you in a better position with a seller. You'll be nearly as good as a cash buyer.


I'd also recommend that you don't contact the home seller directly. Sometimes this can lead you to saying something that you weren't supposed to. It's much easier to just let us do the talking. We're going to be in communication with them, so don't worry about that aspect of the transaction.


Hopefully you can take these tips to heart when you purchase a home. If you have any questions about this issue or if you'd like to learn more, please don't hesitate to contact me!

link.title: Avoid These Common Buyer Mistakes in Charlotte

entry.title: What Is Sellability?
entry.content:
Buying a Charlotte home? Get a full home search 
Selling a Charlotte home?  Get a Home Price Evaluation

Today, I'm going to speak about two different ways to look at a home's sellability. You can look at sellability as a buyer and also as a seller. 

When you look at the sellability of your home as a seller, you should ask yourself why you bought it in the first place. What sold you on your home originally? If you can answer this question, then you know what you need to feature in your home's listing. Chances are that the same selling points that convinced you to buy will also convince someone else to buy. 

As a buyer, the biggest thing to look at is how you might sell the home that you're about to purchase. How would you sell your future home? What features would you highlight, and what problem areas are there with the home? Does it have a large garage, or a big backyard? 

Another question to ask yourself is whether you could sell your home for the amount that you're paying now. Sellability is important when you purchase a home, because houses are investments for the future. You don't want to purchase a property that you can't turn around and sell for a similar price. 

Hopefully this has helped, because the turnaround value of a home should matter to you if you're really investing in your future. If you're looking to buy or sell in Charlotte, please don't hesitate to contact me!

However, it's important to have the proper presentation when you go to build a custom home. It's crucial that you realize the true cost of the upgrades being done to your home, because these can significantly affect the price of the home and may even derail your purchase. Builders tend to hide these costs, so it's important to know what you're actually paying for.

Sometimes builders will also give you the option of using the same lender that they work with, and they will credit you money toward the closing cost of the home if you choose to do business with that same lender. 

It's not a good idea to assume that the builder is always going to give you the greatest deal possible. This is why it's crucial to have a real estate agent working on your behalf. entry.title: What Is the Difference Between Short Sales and Foreclosures?
entry.content:
Buying a Charlotte home? Get a full home search 
Selling a Charlotte home?  Get a Home Price Evaluation 

What's the difference between a short sale and a foreclosure? This is a question we hear a lot, so we thought we would answer it for you here today.

Short sale
If someone purchased a home for $300,000, and still owes $290,000 after a few years, even though the home is now only worth $270,000, they will likely need to sell the home. A short sale is when you go to the bank and ask them to forgive the difference between what you owe and your home is actually worth: in this case, $20,000. Whether the bank will allow a short sale depends on the financial circumstances. People often have a short sale if they lose their job or have to leave town in a hurry. Most banks will grant you permission if the circumstances call for it.

Foreclosure
A foreclosure happens when someone doesn't pay their bills and the bank takes over the property. Here in North Carolina, a deed of trust is what holds the lien holder to the property. In other words, if you don't pay, you don't stay. Once it is a proper foreclosure, the bank will own the property. In these situations, you'll often see the home put up for auction.

There aren't many short sales or foreclosures left in our market, but when they do come they're going quick. You need to make sure you're working with a great agent if you want to scoop up a great deal! If you have any questions about this topic, or if you need real estate assistance of any kind, give us a call or shoot us a quick email. It would be our pleasure to serve you!

entry.title: How to Price Your Home for Top Dollar in Charlotte
entry.content:
There are many great Charlotte area homes for sale. Click here to perform a full home search, or if you're thinking of selling your home, click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation so you know what buyers will pay for your home in today's market. You may also call me at 704-500-0026 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation to answer any of your real estate questions.

This spring we're expecting a busy real estate market in Charlotte. If you're thinking of listing your home, I cannot emphasize how important it will be to get it priced correctly. If your price is too high it will sit on the market, and if it is too low you'll simply get taken advantage of. The key is to find a median, and then let people outbid each other to drive up the price of your home. You want to create the illusion of a good value for your home, because that usually generates buzz and more offers.
  • Look at comparables and competition: You need to do your research and find comparable homes to your own and see what they're valued at and what they're selling for. Look at what has sold, what your competition is selling for, and then find a nice midpoint. 
  • DON'T overprice: Pricing a home is an important first impression on a potential buyer. Essentially, it's your most valuable piece of marketing. When you overprice, buyers will often not give your property a second look, and people will begin to wonder if there is something wrong with your home. This results in you getting $10,000-$20,000 less than what you had originally asked for.
  • Know the Charlotte Market: Pricing is tricky, but having a deep knowledge of your local market always helps. Prices will vary from neighborhood to neighborhood, so your knowledge will need to be extensive. We have excellent researchers on our team that can help you in pinpointing a perfect price that will drive competition and increase the sale price of your home.

Hopefully this information has been helpful to you. If you need assistance getting your home ready for the spring market here in Charlotte, please do not hesitate to contact us via email or phone. We would love to help you sell your home for more money.

The new year is in full swing, and the spring market is right around the corner! Is your home ready to be sold? Today, we have some quick tips to help you get the most of this year's spring selling season! 

Photography is one of the most vital marketing tools you have at your disposal. You can't use an iPhone or a Polaroid to take photos of your home - you need a professional. They will be able to capture the best aspects of your home, and their photos will present a clear and accurate depiction of your home.

We have a 71-point checklist for photography and showings that we use to get our listings maximum exposure. Today, we want to share a few of the items from the checklist with you.
  • Power wash your home: Use a pressure washer to clean the siding, the driveway, the gutters, the windows, and other highly visible areas of your home. This will help the exterior of your home really pop in photographs, especially when we do an aerial shot of your front yard. 
  • Make sure your yard is landscaped well: Trim the bushes and trees, cut the grass, and put down a fresh layer of mulch to liven up your yard. 
  • Declutter: We highly suggest getting rid of items you have around your home that you have no use for any more. Additionally, if there are certain items that make the home feel cluttered, our advice is to put them in storage until the home is sold. A clear, open home has a much better chance of selling. 
  • Dress up the front door: The very first thing a buyer sees is the front door. If you want to give a great first impression, you need to make sure it looks great. Paint it a neutral color and be sure to refinish it if it's made of wood and has started to wear. 
  • Fix cosmetic issues inside the home: Touch up the paint, fix cracks in the wall, repair drywall, and ensure other small damages are repaired. These are things potential buyers will look for, and they will show up in photography as well.  
  • Make your home feel cozy: Take the advice of professionals when it comes to adding a level of coziness to your home. They know the little things that will make for stellar photographs and really draw buyers in. We have a full-time stager who can really help with this! 

If you would like to see the full 71-point checklist for getting your home ready to be photographed, shoot us an email or give us a call. We would love to help you make the most of your home sale!

entry.title: How Much Is Your Home REALLY Worth?
entry.content:
There are many great Charlotte area homes for sale. Click here to perform a full home search, or if you're thinking of selling your home, click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation so you know what buyers will pay for your home in today's market. You may also call me at 704-500-0026 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation to answer any of your real estate questions.
 
Is looking at your tax value a good way to determine how much your home is really worth? It's a question we get all the time, but the answer is pretty straightforward.

In short, looking at the tax value of your home is an unreliable way to determine your  home's value. Tax values are put in place so counties and municipalities can function properly - those assessed values have little, if anything, to do with what's going on inside your home. If you have a large home, but haven't made any upgrades for 25 years, you may find that your tax assessment is much higher than the price your home will actually sell for.            

Most municipalities reassess once every eight years. They will come around and look at your home to see if you've added a pool or any other additions that may add value to your home. After looking at your information, they are going to come up with a ballpark estimate. Sometimes the estimate is a little off, sometimes they're spot on - but most of the time they're not even CLOSE.

Recently, we sold a home for $282,000 even though the tax value was $218,000! By following the tax assessment you could leave a lot of money on the table by underpricing your home, or you could scare off every buyer in the market by overpricing it based on that value. The best thing you can do to find the TRUE value of your home is meet with a local real estate expert. We'll take a look at what's been going on in your neighborhood and the market conditions throughout the area to determine what your home is worth. 

Don't use tax assessments to determine your home value. You can use the tools we provide here on our website to get a more accurate ballpark number, before giving us a call to put an exact price on it. Don't hesitate to reach out to us, we would love to help you make informed decisions in our marketplace.

link.title: How Much Is Your Home REALLY Worth?

entry.title: Pre-Qualified Vs. Pre-Approved - What's The Difference?
entry.content:
There are many great Charlotte area homes for sale. Click here to perform a full home search, or if you're thinking of selling your home, click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation so you know what buyers will pay for your home in today's market. You may also call me at 704-500-0026 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation to answer any of your real estate questions.

A common question we get asked is, "What's the difference between a pre-approval and a pre-qualification." Today, you'll learn what separates the two and why one is much more valuable than the other.

A pre-qualification is when the lender pulls your credit and income to see what your general financial picture is like. There is no verification whatsoever, and a lot of the bigger banks will take this simple step to get you pre-qualified. If you're a seller and someone gives you an offer that is pre-qualified, we suggest you run far away from that offer! 

Why?

With a pre-qualification, nothing has been verified. Tax returns, pay stubs, and debt ratio are not verified during the pre-qualification process and the odds of closing on time, or at all, with a pre-qualified buyer are slim. 

A pre-approval, on the other hand, is when a lender takes the time to look at your entire financial picture. Tax returns, W-2s, paid taxes, income, and debt are all examined and verified. If you receive an offer from a pre-approved buyer, we would suggest you take it very serious and even open negotiations. A pre-approval is a stamp of approval from the bank that a buyer can afford what they say they can. 

People often ask us whether they can negotiate the price of a loan. Big banks such as Wells Fargo or Bank of America have set guidelines for what they charge. With these banks, everything is negotiable. However, local lenders have more options - they can shop around for the best rate, terms, and conditions for your particular situation. 

We personally use American Security Mortgage to help our clients. Our preferred lender will get all of your documents up front so you look like a cash buyer by the time you submit an offer. All you will need is an appraisal once you make an offer, as everything else the seller needs to see will have already been collected. When it comes to finding the right loan package, all your have to do is let our lender know what works for you so your money goes as far as it can when buying your next home! 

If you have any questions about these topics, or would like us to answer a real estate question of yours in a future video, give us a call or shoot us an email. We would love to address your comments and concerns!

entry.content:
There are many great Charlotte area homes for sale. Click here to perform a full home search, or if you're thinking of selling your home, click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation so you know what buyers will pay for your home in today's market. You may also call me at 704-500-0026 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation to answer any of your real estate questions.

The new year is right around the corner, so I thought I would recap the year in real estate for the Charlotte area.

The biggest thing we saw over the last year was the decrease in average days on market. Traditionally, homes sit on the market for 100 to 125 days before selling. In 2014, however, the average days on market was only 75 days! This is about half as long as many other parts of the country.

Although the average market time is 75 days, we're seeing homes sell in only four or five days! For 2013 and 2012 we were still floating around 90-100 days, so we're down about 30% as of this year. I'm not sure whether we'll see this trend continue deep into the new year, but things look pretty good right now.

One thing everyone wants to know about is where home prices are going to be in the next year. Prices aren't going up like they were in the years leading up to the recession, but they are still increasing anywhere from 2%-4%, depending on the area of Charlotte you live in.

What can we expect for next year?

The biggest things driving our local market is the amount of people moving to the area and extremely low interest rates. If interest rates rise in the next year, which is expected, home appreciation may start to level out. However, if rates stay low, we'll probably see another year with solid home appreciation. With all the people moving to our area, you can expect demand for homes to be high, which may also have a positive effect on home values.

If you have any questions about what to expect in our market in the new year, give us call or shoot us an email. We would love to give you the information you need to be an informed buyer or seller of Charlotte real estate!

link.title: What Do Charlotte Market Conditions Mean for You?

entry.title: Listing at the Wrong Time Could Cost You Thousands!
entry.content:
There are many great Charlotte area homes for sale. Click here to perform a full home search, or if you're thinking of selling your home, click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation so you know what buyers will pay for your home in today's market. You may also call me at 704-500-0026 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation to answer any of your real estate questions.

If you try to sell your home in November, December, or January, will you get as much for it as could if you waited? Many agents will tell you that it's the worst time to sell your home - statistically, these months have the lowest amount of sales.

On the other hand, there isn't nearly as much competition among sellers during the late fall and early winter months. When you average the two to see how many homes are actually selling and how long they spend on the market, you'll find that November, December, and January are better months to sell your home, get quicker results, and potentially get a higher dollar amount.

Any time you're looking to sell your home, there's usually is a better time for your particular neighborhood. The most important thing to look at when selling a home is the amount of competition, not only in your neighborhood, but in your price range. If there are 30 homes in your price range active on the market, with only four under contract, the odds of you selling quickly and for top dollar are not in your favor.

So, if you want to maximize your home sale, you need to act strategically. We would love to help you do that in the upcoming months. Give us a call or shoot us an email if you want to take advantage of this wide open market. We look forward to hearing from you soon!

We're giving away tickets to the November 5th game between the Charlotte Hornets and the Miami Heat to show our appreciation. They're great seats, only 13 rows back. So, back to business. What's happening in our market right now? Well, if you want to get a general idea, you can check out www.HotCharlotteDeals.com to see a list of distressed property sales and other homes listed on our local MLS.

Right now, there are 1,500 active listings in the Lake Norman area, with 565 of them under contract. This is extremely high compared to past years. Over the last 30 days we've seen 330 closings in the area!  The list-to-sale price is a fantastic 96.9% and homes are only sitting on the market for about 79 days

In Charlotte, we're seeing similar numbers. In Charlotte and Union County, there are 3,800 homes on the market, with 1,900 of those homes under contract - this means one in every three homes listed is under contract, which is very high. In the last 30 days, 70 homes have sold. Overall, homes are sitting on the market for an average of 73 days, with a list-to-sale ratio of 97.5%.

What's this mean for you? Well, the Lake Norman and Charlotte areas are still incredibly hot. If you're looking to buy or sell a home, your best option is to speak with a real estate professional. Don't hesitate to reach out to us with any of your questions on the market. We would love to serve you!

Stay tuned for more chances to win prizes, as we'll have another drawing in the upcoming months! Thanks, and have a great week!

entry.title: Charlotte Real Estate Market Snapshot
entry.content:
There are many great Charlotte area homes for sale. Click here to perform a full home search, or if you're thinking of selling your home, click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation so you know what buyers will pay for your home in today's market. You may also call me at 704-500-0026 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation to answer any of your real estate questions.

While we're currently experiencing market conditions favorable to sellers, we are still seeing homes come on the market. However, homes are going quickly. If you are buying and having reservations about a home, you need to act quickly - if you're working with a good agent, they will be able to help you spot a good deal and make the right decision before someone else does.

If you're selling, you have a bit of leverage when listing your home. Homeowners who have been trying to sell for the past several months now have a great opportunity to get a great value for their home. Inventory is low, so there aren't as many homes to choose from as there usually are. Because supply is low and interest rates are low, we are starting to see home prices rise steadily. 

The fact that we've seen fewer distressed property sales is a good sign. There are still properties going into short sales and foreclosures, but those numbers are down significantly - from 7.2% of the market last year to 4.8% this year. If you're a buyer waiting for that perfect deal on a distressed property, the right agent can help you find it. However, there isn't much to choose from - most distressed properties stay on the market for no longer than 20 days. The average home in Charlotte is also selling quickly, sitting on the market for an average of 70 days, which is down from 93 days last year.

As you can see, there are some interesting trends happening in our area at the moment. Since things are always changing, it's important to keep yourself in the loop, especially if you plan on buying or selling within the next year. We're always here to help - give us a call or shoot us an email with all of your real estate questions. We look forward to hearing from you soon.

entry.title: Charlotte Market Snapshot
entry.content:
There are many great Charlotte area homes for sale. Click here to perform a full home search, or if you're thinking of selling your home, click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation so you know what buyers will pay for your home in today's market. You may also call me at 704-500-0026 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation to answer any of your real estate questions.

Many people in the Charlotte area have asked about the state of the real estate market, and whether we're still in a seller's market. We're currently seeing homes come onto the market, so there's certainly not a shortage. However, the market is still quite favorable to sellers.

If you're buying and have found a home, but feel hesitant about making an offer, you need to be careful. Homes are going quickly in this market, so you need to work with an agent who knows a good deal when they see one. They will be able to help you make the right decision quicker - that way, you can get the house you're interested in before another agent comes by and purchases it.

If you're selling, you have a good deal of leverage. Folks who have been trying to sell for a while have a great opportunity to do so in this market. Prices are rising because interest rates are still incredibly low, and inventory is still low enough to create demand for your home. 

There are still distressed properties out there, but the numbers are down significantly. If you're a buyer looking for an opportunity to buy a great home for a low price, it may be difficult without the right agent. Because the number of distressed properties has fallen from 7.2% of the market to 4.8%, there is much less to choose from. Additionally, the days on market for distressed homes is only 15-20 days, making it an incredibly competitive segment of the market. On the other hand, the average home is selling in about 70 days, which is down from 93 days at this time last year - which means now is an ideal time to get your home sold pretty quick.

Keep an eye out for our upcoming videos. We'll be looking at specific areas in and around Charlotte to keep you updated on market trends. If you have any real estate related questions, don't hesitate to reach out to us - we would love to hear from you!
